facts.text: Four consolidated appeals brought by special leave against the order of the High Court of Gujarat dated November 27, 1961 summarily dismissing four Special Civil Applications Nos. 704 to 707 of 1961

anchor.surface_text: These four companysolidated appeals are brought, by special leave, against the order of the High Court of Gujarat dated November 27, 1961 summarily dismissing four Special Civil Applications Nos. 704 to 707 of 1961 which had been filed by the appellants under Art. 227 of the Constitution of India for quashing the order of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dated July 18, 1961.

facts.text: Special Civil Applications Nos. 704 to 707 of 1961 filed by the appellants under Art. 227 of the Constitution of India for quashing the order of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dated July 18, 1961

anchor.surface_text: These four companysolidated appeals are brought, by special leave, against the order of the High Court of Gujarat dated November 27, 1961 summarily dismissing four Special Civil Applications Nos. 704 to 707 of 1961 which had been filed by the appellants under Art. 227 of the Constitution of India for quashing the order of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dated July 18, 1961.

facts.text: Appellants applied for companypensation to the Jagir Abolition Officer, Baroda under s. 13 of the Bombay Merged Territories Areas Jagirs Abolition Act, 1953, in respect of their proprietary jagirs

anchor.surface_text: The appellants had applied for companypensation to the Jagir Abolition Officer, Baroda under s. 13 of the Bombay Merged Territories Areas  Jagirs Abolition  Act, 1953, hereinafter referred to as the Jagirs Abolition Act, in respect of their proprietary jagirs.

facts.text: Against the award of companypensation made by the Jagir Abolition Officer the appellants preferred appeals under s. 16 of the Jagirs Abolition Act

anchor.surface_text: Against the award of companypensation made by the Jagir Abolition Officer the appellants preferred appeals under s. 16 of the Jagirs Abolition Act.

facts.text: Appeals were filed before the Revenue Tribunal at Bombay, transferred on the bifurcation of Bombay State to the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal at Ahmedabad

anchor.surface_text: Although these appeals were filed before the Revenue, Tribunal at Bombay, the appeals were transferred, on the bifurcation of Bombay State, to the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal at Ahmedabad, hereinafter called the Tribunal.

facts.text: All these appeals were ultimately dismissed by the Tribunal for number-prosecution on account of number-appearance of the advocate of the appellants

anchor.surface_text: All these appeals were ultimately dismissed by the Tribunal for number-prosecution on account of number-appearance of the advocate of the appellants.

facts.text: Orders of dismissal made on February 1, 2 and 3, 1961

anchor.surface_text: As the orders of dismissal was made on February 1, 2 and 3, 1961 and the applications for restoration were made only on May 6, 1961, the Tribunal held that they were time-barred.

facts.text: Appellants filed applications for restoration before the Tribunal on May 6, 1961

anchor.surface_text: Against the dismissal of the appeals for number-prosecution the appellants filed applications for restoration before the Tribunal on May 6, 1961.

facts.text: Orders passed dismissing the appeals were received by appellants on April 9 and April 20, 1961

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytended that since the orders passed dismissing the appeals were received by them on April 9 and April 20, 1961, the restitution applications filed on May 6, 1961 were within 30 days of the receipt of the order of dismissal

facts.text: Tribunal rejected the applications for restoration holding they were barred under Art. 168 of the Limitation Act read with Regulation 55 and O.41, rr. 17 and 19 of the Civil Procedure Code

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal rejected the applications holding that they were barred under Art. 168 of the Limitation Act read with Regulation 55 and 0.41, rr. 17 and 19 of the Civil Procedure Code.

facts.text: Tribunal held applications for restoration should have been made within 30 days from the date of the order of dismissal

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the Tribunal was that the applications for restoration should have been made within 30 days from the date of the order of dismissal.

facts.text: Appellants moved the High Court of Gujarat under Art. 227 but applications dismissed in limine

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the order of dismissal of the restoration applications the appellants moved the High Court of Gujarat under Art. 227 of the Constitution of India but their applications were dismissed in Iimine.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows these appeals, sets aside the order of the Gujarat High Court dismissing Special Civil Applications 704 to 707 of 1961

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we allow these appeals, set aside the order of the Gujarat High Court dismissing Special Civil Applications 704 to 707 of 1961 and hold that the order of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing the restoration applications Nos. GRT.D. 10 to 13 of 1961 dated July 18, 1961 is defective in law and must be set aside.

facts.text: Order of Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing restoration applications Nos. GRT.D. 10 to 13 of 1961 dated July 18, 1961 is defective in law and set aside

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we allow these appeals, set aside the order of the Gujarat High Court dismissing Special Civil Applications 704 to 707 of 1961 and hold that the order of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing the restoration applications Nos. GRT.D. 10 to 13 of 1961 dated July 18, 1961 is defective in law and must be set aside.

facts.text: Orders of Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing Appeals Nos. REV.A. 27, 28, 29 and 30 of 1960 are ultra vires and illegal and set aside

anchor.surface_text: We also hold that the orders of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing Appeals Nos. REV.A. 27. 28, 29 and 30 of 1960 are ultra vires and illegal and must be set aside and order that these four appeals should go back to the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal for being reheard and dealt with in accordance with law.

facts.text: Four appeals Nos. REV.A. 27, 28, 29 and 30 of 1960 to be reheard by Gujarat Revenue Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: We also hold that the orders of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing Appeals Nos. REV.A. 27. 28, 29 and 30 of 1960 are ultra vires and illegal and must be set aside and order that these four appeals should go back to the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal for being reheard and dealt with in accordance with law.

facts.text: Appellants contended that applications for restoration were within 30 days of receipt of order under Regulation 21

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytended that since the orders passed dismissing the appeals were received by them on April 9 and April 20, 1961, the restitution applications filed on May 6, 1961 were within 30 days of the receipt of the order of dismissal and hence the applications for restoration were made in time under Regulation 21 of the Bombay Revenue Tribunal Regulations.

facts.text: Appellants prayed that restoration applications be allowed as they were prevented for sufficient cause from appearing

anchor.surface_text: The appellants also prayed that the applications for restoration should be allowed as they were prevented for sufficient cause from appearing at the hearing of the appeals.

facts.text: Appellants contended Tribunal orders dated February 1, 2 and 3, 1961 illegal as dismissed for non-prosecution without decision on merits

anchor.surface_text: The first question for companysideration is whether the orders of the Tribunal dated February 1, 2 and 3, 1961 are illegal and ultra vires because the Tribunal dismissed the appeals for number- prosecution and there was numberdecision of the appeals on merits.

facts.text: Jagir Abolition Officer is referred to as Collector in sections 13 and 14

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 of the Jagirs Abolition Act provides that any jagirdar entitled to companypensation under section 11 or 12 shall, on or before the 31st day of July 1958 apply in writing to the Collector for determining the amount of companypensation payable to him under the said section.

facts.text: Appeals against Collector's award lie to Bombay Revenue Tribunal constituted under Bombay Revenue Tribunal Act, 1957

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 provides for an appeal against the Collectors award and is to the following effect An appeal shall lie against an award of the Collector to the Bombay Revenue Tribunal companystituted under the Bombay Revenue Tribunal Act, 1957 numberwithstanding anything companytained in the said Act.

facts.text: Award by Collector and decision of Revenue Tribunal final and conclusive

anchor.surface_text: Section 20 provides for the finality of the award and of the decision of the Revenue Tribunal and reads as follows The award made by the Collector subject to an appeal to the Bombay Revenue Tribunal and the decision of the Bombay Revenue Tribunal on the appeal shall be final and companyclusive and shall number be questioned in any suit or proceeding in any Court.

issues.text: The first question for consideration is whether the orders of the Tribunal dated February 1, 2 and 3, 1961 are illegal and ultra vires because the Tribunal dismissed the appeals for non-prosecution and there was no decision of the appeals on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The first question for companysideration is whether the orders of the Tribunal dated February 1, 2 and 3, 1961 are illegal and ultra vires because the Tribunal dismissed the appeals for number-prosecution and there was numberdecision of the appeals on merits.

issues.text: The second question of law for consideration in this case is whether, on a proper construction of Regulations 19, 20 and 21 of the Bombay Revenue Tribunal Regulations, 1958, the Tribunal was right in taking the view that the applications for restoration made by the appellants were barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The second question of law for companysideration in this case is whether, on a proper companystruction of Regulations 19, 20 and 21 of the Bombay Revenue Tribunal Regulations, 1958, the Tribunal was right in taking the view that the applications for restoration made by the appellants were barred by limitation.

It was companytended that it was obligatory on the part of the Tribunal to decide the appeals on merits and record its decision in view of s. 17 of the Jagirs Abolition Act

arguments.claim: Applications for restoration barred by limitation under Art.168 Limitation Act read with Reg.55 and CPC O.41 rr.17,19 from date of dismissal order

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal rejected the applications holding that they were barred under Art. 168 of the Limitation Act read with Regulation 55 and 0.41, rr. 17 and 19 of the Civil Procedure Code. The view taken by the Tribunal was that the applications for restoration should have been made within 30 days from the date of the order of dismissal. As the orders of dismissal was made on February 1, 2 and 3, 1961 and the applications for restoration were made only on May 6, 1961, the Tribunal held that they were time-barred.

arguments.claim: Tribunal obligated under s.17(1) Jagirs Act to decide appeals on merits and record decision even if appellant absent; no power to dismiss for non-prosecution

anchor.surface_text: in our opinion, the companytention put forward by the appellants is well-founded and must be accepted as companyrect. Section 13 of the Jagirs Abolition Act provides that any jagirdar entitled to companypensation under section 11 or 12 shall, on or before the 31st day of July 1958 apply in writing to the Collector for determining the amount of companypensation payable to him under the said section.

arguments.claim: s.20 finality requires actual decision on merits; 'decide' in s.17 means on merits, not mere disposal

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of the language of s. 17 1 of the Jagirs Abolition Act and in the companytext of s. 20 of the Jagirs Abolition Act we are of the opinion that it is obligatory on the part of the Tribunal to decide an appeal on merits even though there is default in the appearance of the appellants and to record its decision regarding the merits of the appeal.

arguments.claim: Reg.19 allows dismissal for non-appearance or decide on merits; Reg.20 restoration applies to both ex-parte decisions and dismissals for non-prosecution

anchor.surface_text: The second question of law for companysideration in this case is whether, on a proper companystruction of Regulations 19, 20 and 21 of the Bombay Revenue Tribunal Regulations, 1958, the Tribunal was right in taking the view that the applications for restoration made by the appellants were barred by limitation. ... We are unable to accept this submission as companyrect. In our opinion, the language of Regulation 20, on its true interpretation, applies number only to a case where the appeal has been decided on merits but also to a case where the appeal has been dismissed for want of prosecution under Regulation 19 1 .

arguments.claim: Reg.21 limitation of 30 days from receipt of dismissal order applies; appellants' applications within time

anchor.surface_text: If the view that we have taken as to the interpretation of Regulation 20 is companyrect, it follows that Regulation 21 applies to the present case and the period of limitation prescribed by that Regulation being 30 days from the date of receipt of the order of dismissal of the appeal, the applications of restoration made by the appellants in all the four cases were well within the period of limitation prescribed by Regulation 21.

arguments.claim: Tribunal's dismissal orders of appeals ultra vires and illegal; must be set aside and reheard

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we allow these appeals, set aside the order of the Gujarat High Court dismissing Special Civil Applications 704 to 707 of 1961 and hold that the order of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing the restoration applications Nos. GRT.D. 10 to 13 of 1961 dated July 18, 1961 is defective in law and must be set aside. We also hold that the orders of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing Appeals Nos. REV.A. 27. 28, 29 and 30 of 1960 are ultra vires and illegal and must be set aside and order that these four appeals should go back to the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal for being reheard and dealt with in accordance with law.

holdings.text: it is obligatory on the part of the Tribunal to decide an appeal on merits even though there is default in the appearance of the appellants and to record its decision regarding the merits of the appeal

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the language of s. 17 1 of the Jagirs Abolition Act and in the context of s. 20 of the Jagirs Abolition Act we are of the opinion that it is obligatory on the part of the Tribunal to decide an appeal on merits even though there is default in the appearance of the appellants and to record its decision regarding the merits of the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and contextual interpretation of s.17(1) and s.20 of Jagirs Abolition Act requires decision on merits; dismissal for non-prosecution not a 'decision'

holdings.text: the Tribunal has no power to dismiss an appeal for non-prosecution but it is obligatory on its part to decide the appeal on merits and to record its decision even though there is default on the part of the appellant to appear in the appeal

anchor.surface_text: In the context of s. 20 and in view of the express language of s. 17 1 of the Jagirs Abolition Act we are of opinion that the Tribunal has no power to dismiss an appeal for non-prosecution but it is obligatory on its part to decide the appeal on merits and to record its decision even though there is default on the part of the appellant to appear in the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.17(1) mandates deciding and recording decision on merits; s.20 finality implies substantive decision, not mere dismissal

holdings.text: the language of Regulation 20, on its true interpretation, applies not only to a case where the appeal has been decided on merits but also to a case where the appeal has been dismissed for want of prosecution under Regulation 19(1)

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this submission as correct. anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the language of s. 17 1 of the Jagirs Abolition Act and in the context of s. 20 of the Jagirs Abolition Act we are of the opinion that it is obligatory on the part of the Tribunal to decide an appeal on merits even though there is default in the appearance of the appellants and to record its decision regarding the merits of the appeal.

For these reasons we allow these appeals, set aside the order of the Gujarat High Court dismissing Special Civil Applications 704 to 707 of 1961 and hold that the order of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing the restoration applications Nos. GRT.D. 10 to 13 of 1961 dated July 18, 1961 is defective in law and mus
en- sation in the manner and according to the method provided for in sub-section  1  of section 23 and section 24 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894. S

anchor.surface_text: In the context of s. 20 and in view of the express language of s. 17 1 of the Jagirs Abolition Act we are of opinion that the Tribunal has no power to dismiss an appeal for non-prosecution but it is obligatory on its part to decide the appeal on merits and to record its decision even though there is default on the part of the appellant to appear in the appeal.

For these reasons we allow these appeals, set aside the order of the Gujarat High Court dismissing Special Civil Applications 704 to 707 of 1961 and hold that the order of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing the restoration applications Nos. GRT.D. 10 to 13 of 1961 dated July 18, 1961 is defective in law and mus

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this submission as correct. In our opinion, the language of Regulation 20, on its true interpretation, applies not only to a case where the appeal has been decided on merits but also to a case where the appeal has been dismissed for want of prosecution under Regulation 19 1 .

For these reasons we allow these appeals, set aside the order of the Gujarat High Court dismissing Special Civil Applications 704 to 707 of 1961 and hold that the order of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing the restoration applications Nos. GRT.D. 10 to 13 of 1961 dated July 18, 1961 is defective in law and mus
s but also to a case where the appeal has been dismissed for want of prosecution under Regulation 19 1 . The reason is that in Regulation 19 1  and 19

anchor.surface_text: If the view that we have taken as to the interpretation of Regulation 20 is correct, it follows that Regulation 21 applies to the present case and the period of limitation prescribed by that Regulation being 30 days from the date of receipt of the order of dismissal of the appeal, the applications of restoration made by the appellants in all the four cases were well within the period of limitation prescribed by Regulation 21.

For these reasons we allow these appeals, set aside the order of the Gujarat High Court dismissing Special Civil Applications 704 to 707 of 1961 and hold that the order of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing the restoration applications Nos. GRT.D. 10 to 13 of 1961 dated July 18, 1961 is defective in law and mus

For these reasons we allow these appeals, set aside the order of the Gujarat High Court dismissing Special Civil Applications 704 to 707 of 1961 and hold that the order of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing the restoration applications Nos. GRT.D. 10 to 13 of 1961 dated July 18, 1961 is defective in law and mus
by the appellants in all the four cases were well within the period of limitation prescribed by Regulation 21. It follows, therefore, that t

anchor.surface_text: We also hold that the orders of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing Appeals Nos. REV.A. 27. 28, 29 and 30 of 1960 are ultra vires and illegal and must be set aside and order that these four appeals should go back to the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal for being reheard and dealt with in accordance with law.

For these reasons we allow these appeals, set aside the order of the Gujarat High Court dismissing Special Civil Applications 704 to 707 of 1961 and hold that the order of the Gujarat Revenue Tribunal dismissing the restoration applications Nos. GRT.D. 10 to 13 of 1961 dated July 18, 1961 is defective in law and mus
